key_insight: The paper adapts psychometric testing to reliably measure, validate, and intentionally shape personality-like traits in large language models, showing instruction-tuned models yield consistent trait scores and can be steered to mimic specific personality profiles.
problem_solved: Provides a rigorous, validated framework to quantify and control personality-like behaviors in LLMs—addressing the lack of standardized measurement and comparability across models and tuning regimes.
method: Administer standardized psychometric instruments (e.g., Big Five style questionnaires) to LLMs via controlled prompts and score their responses to produce trait profiles.
Assess psychometric properties (internal consistency, test–retest reliability, convergent/discriminant validity) across model families and tuning conditions.
Demonstrate shaping of personality profiles through instruction tuning or prompt conditioning and validate resulting behavioral changes on downstream tasks.
impact: Gives practitioners a principled toolkit to audit, compare, and design model personalities for safer, more predictable agents and to evaluate behavioral changes after tuning or deployment.
visual_elements: Pipeline flowchart: prompt → model response → scoring → psychometric validation
Radar or bar charts comparing Big Five trait scores across models and tuning stages
Heatmap/matrix of psychometric metrics (reliability and validity) per model
Before/after example panel showing downstream task outputs with neutral vs. shaped personality
paper_title: A psychometric framework for evaluating and shaping personality traits in large language models
paper_authors: Gregory Serapio-García, Mustafa Safdari, Clément Crepy, Luning Sun, Stephen Fitz
